title: WNZK
text:
WNZK is a <a href="radio%20station">radio station</a> in <a href="Dearborn%20Heights%2C%20Michigan">Dearborn Heights, Michigan</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>.
WNZK began broadcasting October 12, 1985, with the western <a href="Detroit">Detroit</a> suburb of <a href="westland%2C%20Michigan">Westland</a> as its <a href="city%20of%20license">city of license</a>; it switched to Dearborn Heights by 1990. According to the <a href="Federal%20Communications%20Commission">FCC</a> online <a href="https%3A//transition.fcc.gov/fcc-bin/amq%3Flist%3D0%26amp%3Bfacid%3D5348">database</a>, WNZK is the only <a href="AM%20broadcasting">AM radio</a> station in North America on two frequencies: 690 <a href="kHz">kHz</a> during the daytime and at 680 kHz at night. This is to protect the nighttime pattern of <a href="Montreal">Montreal</a>, <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>'s <a href="CKGM">CKGM</a>, a <a href="clear-channel%20station">clear-channel station</a> on 690.
Owned by the <a href="Birach%20Broadcasting%20Corporation">Birach Broadcasting Corporation</a>, WNZK carries <a href="ethnic%20group">ethnic</a> <a href="Radio%20programming">programming</a>, mainly targeted toward listeners of <a href="Arab%20American">Arab</a> and Eastern European descent, including both locally- and non-locally-produced programming (such as news reports from the <a href="BBC%20World%20Service">BBC World Service</a>'s <a href="BBC%20Arabic">Arabic service</a>). WNZK also airs some talk shows in English, including the long-running "Ask Your Neighbor" with Bob Allison (which began on <a href="WWJ%20%28AM%29">WWJ</a> in the 1960s).
With a <a href="transmitter">transmitter</a> <a href="Power%20%28physics%29">power</a> of 2500 <a href="watt">watt</a>s, WNZK identifies as "The Station of the Nations." (97.9 FM in Detroit aired a similar ethnic format for many years with similar calls (WMZK) and the same "Station of the Nations" slogan until 1980; it is now <a href="WJLB">WJLB</a>.)
